So the paper that *inspired* Doug Engelbart's 1962 paper on Augmenting Human Intellect (the one that led to the personal computer in 68) was all about conceptual frameworks

And *that* paper was about multi-discliplinery collabs and also introduced "map rooms" -- a kind of room-sized physical multiplayer wiki of index cards

I dropped this loooong blog post on Friday -- it's 50% spelunking computing history, and 50% imagining future embodied computing environments

As you might have seen in the last boost, I've started a new server directory site to help people sign up on Mastodon and the Fediverse:

➡️ https://fedi.garden

If you want to follow the project, its account is at:

➡️ @FediGarden

Reasons for making this directory:

-It will list both Mastodon and non-Mastodon servers.
-It has a maximum size, megaservers aren't listed.
-It's manually curated and has safety/reliability requirements.

As far as I know, no one else is doing this.

Soft launching a curated directory of Fediverse servers to join:

➡️ https://fedi.garden

To be listed, a site has to:

-Obey the Mastodon Covenant (but doesn't have to be running Mastodon)

-Have fewer than 50,000 registered members

-Be open for public registration, either directly or through requests

Unlike https://joinmastodon.org, this site will accept non-Mastodon instances, and has an upper size limit

Unlike https://instances.social etc this site is curated.

You should read @Mer__edith's thread on all this,¹ and it's worth remembering what @signalapp does and does not do.

Signal does not protect you from:
• an untrustworthy chat partner
• a compromised device
• corporate device management
• your device's Operating System

Signal does protect you from:
• a hack of the Signal servers
• a subpoena of the Signal servers
• the wire between you and the Signal servers
• the employees at Signal

¹ https://mastodon.world/@Mer__edith/109751701529562752

This is a really good paper:

https://www.arxiv-vanity.com/papers/2212.03551/

Gets at a thing that has long worried me: Experts in the field can use conversational shorthand like "believe" and "know" with little risk. Outsiders hear those terms and naturally anthropomorphize.

LLMs are powerful and useful, but require human oversight. Just because GPT-3 says it doesn't make it so. We need to explain in ways that highlights risk to ordinary folks.

Came my way via @simon.

title: Access is not the same as accessibility: A framework for making research papers truly open – arXiv.org blog

last_post.content:
Very glad to see the #arxiv steps toward #accessibility (#a11y). These include "offering well-formatted #HTML, alongside #PDF and #TeX source."
https://blog.arxiv.org/2023/01/19/access-is-not-the-same-as-accessibility-a-framework-for-making-research-papers-truly-open/

PS: There are 𝘮𝘢𝘯𝘺 reasons to offer well-formatted HTML alongside PDF, or to stop publishing PDF-only. Accessibility is first, followed closely by making work friendly to mobile users, users with low bandwidth, and users who need to text-mine, cut/paste, or use machine translation.

Aristotle claimed that identical regular tetrahedra could be packed in a way that fills space. It seems unlikely if you actually try it - but only in 1925 was it proved impossible. And only in 2010 did people prove a nontrivial upper bound on the density of the packing you can achieve, namely

0.9999999999999999999999974

On the other hand, the densest known packing has density about .8563 - there's a discussion and picture on Wolfram's website:

https://blog.wolfram.com/2010/08/30/tetrahedra-packing/

(1/n)

title: Bitwarden design flaw: Server side iterations

last_post.content:
People have been asking me about #Bitwarden ever since #LastPass has been breached. While I never took an in-depth look, I now at least evaluated the claims regarding their encryption:

https://palant.info/2023/01/23/bitwarden-design-flaw-server-side-iterations/

While the password manager being completely open-source with the option to self-host is great, otherwise I’m not too impressed. The issues in particular:

· Server-side iterations mechanism does not provide any security value. They should have known about it at least since 2020 when @dchest wrote about it, probably even since 2018 when I discussed the same flaw in LastPass. Yet they are still using it for their PR claims.
· 100,000 PBKDF2 iterations on the client side is too low, with the current OWASP recommendation being 310,000. They updated this setting (hopefully upgrading existing accounts as well) in 2018 seemingly to match LastPass and failed to adjust ever since.
· Bitwarden allows users to configure 5,000 iterations without even warning them. Not only is this value dangerously low, supporting it also allows a compromised production server to ask the client for a password hashed with 5,000 iterations – regardless of the actual setting.
· Bitwarden users have been pointing out the key derivation parameters being inadequate since at least 2018. Development of Argon2 support only started two weeks ago, and it isn’t coming from the core developers.

On the bright side, vault data is completely encrypted. No unencrypted URLs and such.

@bitwarden

title: Revealed: how US transition to electric cars threatens environmental havoc

last_post.content:
Fantastic new study by the great Thea Riofrancos et al

This research is a very, very positive and important contribution to showing the benefits of active and public transport, and a sign that climate action can be designed to be beneficial, with minimal environmental impacts.

There are plenty of people who trade in absolutism in climate solutions - who make an active effort to ensure we avoid alternative futures that ease the pressures of this massive change.

This paper is a nice corrective against them.

https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/jan/24/us-electric-vehicles-lithium-consequences-research

title: The Value Of Owning More Books Than You’ll Ever Read

last_post.content:
Do you own far more books than you'll ever read?

<raises hand>

Here's a useful way to think about it: All those books are what Nassim Nicholas Taleb calls an "antilibrary"

They are the whitespace around your knowledge

They keep you humble -- sure, you know stuff, but behold all the things you *don't* know!

Or, as I put it ... they're a form of "intellectual orienteering"

My essay: https://clivethompson.medium.com/the-value-of-owning-more-books-than-youll-ever-read-3d60a6046994

title: The Value Of Owning More Books Than You’ll Ever Read

last_post.content:
Do you own far more books than you'll ever read?

<raises hand>

Here's a useful way to think about it: All those books are what Nassim Nicholas Taleb calls an "antilibrary"

They are the whitespace around your knowledge

They keep you humble -- sure, you know stuff, but behold all the things you *don't* know!

Or, as I put it ... they're a form of "intellectual orienteering"

My essay: https://clivethompson.medium.com/the-value-of-owning-more-books-than-youll-ever-read-3d60a6046994

A "friend" link if you're not a Medium subscriber: https://clivethompson.medium.com/the-value-of-owning-more-books-than-youll-ever-read-3d60a6046994?sk=d9575f6411ee9d9a756e2b59ab1e9b2e

title: Webb Unveils Dark Side of Pre-stellar Ice Chemistry

last_post.content:
Surprisingly not a still from a sci-fi movie, this new #JWST image shows us the central portion of the star-forming Chamaeleon I molecular cloud.

The cold, wispy cloud material (blue, center) is illuminated in the infrared by the glow of the young, outflowing protostar Ced 110 IRS 4 (orange, upper left). The ices in the cloud absorb some of the light of background stars (orange dots), allowing us to detect them.

Read more: https://webbtelescope.org/contents/news-releases/2023/news-2023-106

1/
#astrdon #astronomy #space

Ivory is out! By far and away my favorite Mastodon app.

Before @ivory, Mastodon felt like a Twitter clone that I wasn’t really “getting”, bouncing between apps and not finding any that fit me.

With Ivory, Mastodon became not only a drop-in replacement for Twitter for me, but an upgrade that’s actually so much better than Twitter that I don’t think about it at all anymore.

I immediately subscribed to the highest Ivory plan. They deserve our support!

https://apps.apple.com/us/app/ivory-for-mastodon-by-tapbots/id6444602274?l=en

My project right now is #BikeHopper, an open-source directions app for transit+bikes.

https://github.com/bikehopper/bikehopper-ui

It uses #OpenStreetMap and a modified version of GraphHopper.

Two main benefits over other trip planning apps:
1. Bike-on-bus, bike-on-train etc. options
2. Tries really hard to find low-stress routes, avoiding main roads

Research papers increasingly refer to websites like GitHub for code, which may be a problem...

About 20% of preprints referred to GitHub in 2021. Yet, these web pages are often not archived, jeopardizing their long-term availability.

"The growing use of Git Hosting Platforms in scholarly publications points to an urgent and growing need for dedicated efforts to archive their holdings in order to preserve research code"

via https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2208.04895
#OpenScience #OpenSource @academicchatter

A collection of the papers for the @ICAHDQ 2022 preconference “What Comes After Disinformation Studies” is now online, published by the Center for Information, Technology, and Public Life. It critiques the current disinformation discourse.

Involved in the preconference and special issue were @kreissdaniel, Meredith Clark, @alicetiara, Sylvain Parasie, Rachel Kuo, Elaine Schnabel, @shannimcg, and yours truly.

https://citap.pubpub.org/what-comes-after-disinformation

Ok, so.

Tweets look really good when you send them in Messages on iOS/macOS. Mastodon posts… don’t. So I built a little tool that makes them much nicer to look at:

https://mstdn.link

Add ?to={any Mastodon post URL} to the end of that domain and when you send it to a friend, you get the nice looking preview. Of course the page makes it easy to paste a URL in. And there’s a Shortcut to make it even easier on iOS or macOS.
